Award.AbstractNarration:
The commercial success of data mining, and the great research interest
that this area attracts, prove that there is a need for analyzing and
understanding data that goes well beyond classical database queries.
Users are often particularly interested in understanding the causal
relationship between data items and the reasons for observations.

Current database systems cannot explicitly model the causal structure
within data (although it is often implicit in the data), and thus offer
no specific support for causal queries. In the absence of information
about causal relationships, users have to rely on techniques for mining
for statistically significant patterns in data. Causal relationships
are often simply concluded from statistical dependencies. This can lead
to inaccurate conclusions; correlation does not necessarily imply
causation.

This project creates the foundations for a new breed of databases
called causal databases. Causal databases can model causal information,
and allow for queries regarding causality and explanations, which are
beyond the scope of current databases. They can also take advantage of
causal information that is implicit, but unexploited, in some current
databases, such as those for large engineering projects. In the
project, new database models and query languages for representing and
transforming causal information are developed, with particular focus on
large engineering databases and scientific databases. In addition,
efficient and scalable techniques for processing causality and
computing explanations in large causal databases are developed. This
involves both work on integrating causality processing into traditional
database query processing architectures and the development of special
datastream techniques for scaling up to the most data-intensive
applications.

Further information on the project can be found at the project web
page: http://www.cs.cornell.edu/databases/causality/

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we worked on many topics related to the foundationsof causality and causality in databases.  On the foundational front,we started with the definiton of causality proposed by Judea Pearl andJoseph Halpern (PI).  We (a) proposed an improvement of the definiton,(b) showed how causal models could be represented compactly, (c) showed how toadd a notion of "normality" to the notion in a way that both captured human intuitions and dealt with problems with the definition, (d) characterized the complexity of many problems related to causality, with a focus on causal queries in databases, and (e) proposed adefinition of probabilistic causality. 


With regard to causal databases, we considered modifications to theHalpern-Pearl definition that would make it more appropriate and more tractable for database queries.  These modfications allowed us to do things like rank causes and explain contributions to relational aggregate functions, aiding users in identifying errors in uncertain or untrusted data.  We then developed a framework and a system forexplaining query results.  Today, many users with a variety of backgrounds seek to extract high-level information from datasets. In a typical scenario, a user integrates a number of data sets, computes some statistics, then wants to find (causal) explanations for what she sees: Why are these data values outliers? Why are two graphs similar (or dissimilar)?  Why is this value so high (low)?  We developed a framework for finding explanations for numerical SQL queries (i.e., queries with an aggregate operator, or some arithmetic expression combining multiple such queries).  We then developed an "Explanation-Ready" database, which computes on-the-fly complexexplanations to query answers. Using this work as a basis, we wereable to explore the semantics of richer explanations in databases,which used probabilistic reasoning.

 
In a final thread of work, we examined semantics-based concurrency, where we weaken the usual causality in consistency protocols. Datastores today rely on distribution and replication to achieve improved performanceand fault-tolerance. But the correctness of many applications depends on strong consistency properties -- something that can impose substantial overheads, since it requires coordinating the behavior of multiple nodes.  We extended this work to consistency in large-scale geo-replicated systems. Online services distribute and replicate state across geographically diverse data centers and direct user requests to the closest or least loaded site. While effectively ensuring low-latency responses, this approach is at odds with maintaining cross-site consistency.  We provided ways of effectively  maintaining consistency.

This work was published in major conference and leading journals, andwas the subject of numerous invited talks and tutorials.  Much of the workwas summarized in "Actual Causality", by Halpern, recently publishedby MIT Press.
